acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96 hours LC50=0.113mg/L of the crustacea (Mysid Shrimp)) (ECETOC TR91, 2003).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the testing data of rabbit LD50 (dermal route) of 22.3mg/kg (CICAD 61 (2004)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 10mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 10mg/kg and 7.49 mg/kg (CICAD 61 (2004)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, in vivo germ/somatic cell mutagenicity tests, in vivo germ/somatic cell genotoxicity tests, and no strong positive data on in vitro mutatogenicity tests (several indices), described in CICAD 61 (2004).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Inorganic compounds containing no oxygen and halogen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale:
Based on the following description found among the data on cyanide in CICAD (2004): "conjunctival hyperaemia with mild chemosis, lacrimation, photophobia, and tingling sensation", although the substance should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety.
Although the present substance is a salt of a weak acid and a strong base and the pH of its aqueous solution is expected to exceed 11.5, no description specifying the pH could be found, so classification by pH was not conducted.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale:
Based on the following description found in CICAD (2004): "Cyanide is slightly irritating to the skin and eye", although no data is available for potassium cyanide.
Although the present substance is a salt of a weak acid and a strong base and the pH of its aqueous solution is expected to exceed 11.5, no description specifying the pH could be found, so classification by pH was not conducted.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Stable to water - water solubility: 71.8g/100mL, ICSC (2004)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (thyroid, kidney, liver, spleen, central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (thyroid, kidney, liver, spleen, central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "degeneration of the kidneys, liver and thyroid gland," "cytoplasmic vacuolation possibly reflecting edematous degeneration of the epithelial cells lining proximal convoluted tubules; spheroids in the anterior horn of spinal cord, loss of nerve cells in the hippocampus, Purkinje cell damage, neuropathological findings including cerebellar deficiency" (CICAD 61 2004). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "coma, bradypnea, parkinsonian syndromes (following ingestion)," "severe damage to the putamen and globus pallidus (observed in autopsy specimens)," "coma, apnea, metabolic acidosis, convulsions (within an hour of exposure)" (HSDB (2000)). A brain disorder is indicated - which is considered an unusual case, given the absence of similar data and the description to the effect that "this clinical report is the first of its kind concerning Parkinson's disease in relation to the toxicity of cyanogen compounds." The effects are observed in the central nervous system.
